So widgets are essentially at its core a
UI element that can either present and
organize information or make your UI
interactable through things like buttons
or sliders. And I like to categorize
widgets into two categories and they are
content widgets and layout widgets. So,
let's dive right into that.
Content widgets essentially let you
display content using assets that you
bring in into your content browser onto
your UI. And content widgets also take
up layout space. You'll probably be
hearing this concept of layout space a
ton throughout this presentation. So,
layout space is exactly what it means.
It's the amount of space that a widget
takes up inside your UI. So, if my text
is this long, this is how much space
that is going to take up inside on my
screen, right? If I'm making a menu with
my text this long, this is how much
space my text is taking up. Remember
this concept because we're going to be
switching this layout space up a bit,
quite a bit later on.
These are the three content widgets
which are extremely useful for I want to
say 99% of use cases that you need in
UEFN because you know it's an these are
images, text and a widget switcher. So
let's get an example to um help
illustrate what this how this is used.
Right? So I have this nifty um health
bar widget that we have showing on the
bottom left of the screen. um a player
would see this when they're in game.
Then this widget is used to track number
one, your health, which is the um the
green bar that that's in a circle with
the text in the middle that says 100.
That's a player's current health. And
the player shield, which is that orange
bar on the right.
So, if we take a look at this widget
inside UMG,
an image block is used to display either
a texture or a material. And an example
of this is the black frame that appears
on the back. There's a texture that we
create in the tool called Figma. And
this is a texture because it doesn't
need to be dynamically updated according
to what's happening in the game. You
need it for decorative purposes. You
need it as a background for your player
health, your player shields, and the
health number. And so we use an image
block to bring in a texture that we
exported from Figma into UFN. And that
allows us to display it inside UMG.
On the other hand, that health bar, the
green radial bar that's circling the um
this frame that we talked about, that's
a health bar material. And materials
essentially let you, you know,
dynamically update based on what's
happening in your game. So, as a
player's gaining or losing health inside
your game, um this radial health bar
increases or decreases depending on
that.
So, image blocks are really useful for
displaying both of them. They are really
versatile in any use case that you want.
Um yeah,
now moving on to text block. Um I'm not

essentially what it is. It is text. Um
the health numbers in the middle that
100 that is a text block. And there are

this text can be dynamically updated

So let's go through something the third
useful content widget which is I think
pretty underrated right now and um is
pretty versatile in my opinion too and
this is the widget switcher. So the
widget switcher lets you cycle between
groups of widgets that are contained
inside it. And so if I have let's say
five widgets inside my widget switcher,
I can switch between the first widget to
the third widget to the fifth widget
depending on what my game is about.
Right? So to show this, let me show an
example.
So I'm walking up to a button to show a
UI. And in this menu, there's two tabs.
Clicking on tab one shows some content
for tab one. Tab two shows some content
for tab two. Right?
If we take a look at this inside UMG,
we can see that all of the content for
tab one and tab 2 is located inside a
widget switcher. And
basically I'm using a a property called
the active widget index on the widget
switcher to cycle between both of them.
So an active widget index is basically
similar to an array. Um it starts at
zero which means I want to point to the
widget in the first position and that is
my content in tab one. If I switch it to
one, it goes to content for tab two. And
so you can imagine how useful this can
be, not even just for menus, but also if
I want to display different states on my
player's health, if I'm, you know, if
I'm eliminated, I want to show a little
skull icon on my on my health bar. I can

know, swap in a skull icon. And when I'm
respawn, I can swap it out again if I
wanted to.
So, those are your three really like
basic and simple content widgets that
you really need to start off with in
UMG, right? But content widgets aren't
going to do much for you if you don't
use what we call layout widgets.
Layout widgets, also known as
containers. I'm going to be switching
back and forth between them throughout
this presentation. So, um, yeah, layout
widgets essentially let you organize the
content widgets that we saw just now to
show on the UI using a set of rules that
are unique to each layout widget. While
content widgets take up layout space,
layout widgets manipulate layout space.
So, if my text block is taking up this
amount of space, if I use a specific
layout widget to, you know, manipulate
it a bit, it can take up this amount of
space, but my text is still this long.
So that's essentially what layout
widgets do for you.
So there's three really common layout
widgets that everyone should know about
when trying to get started in UMG, and
that is the overlay, stack box, and grid
panel.

the drawer itself. If I use an overlay
with them, it looks like this. Simple
concept to understand, right? And to

The next useful widget is a stackbox. A

And the easiest way to visualize this

The one I like to really cover is grid

let's take a look at it.

while the paper background is on layer
zero to ensure that it always appears on
top. And then I nudged it about 50
pixels up in this case. You're seeing
negative 48.96 and something something.
But that's it being nudged up just above

How do I get started even, you know,

hot tips for how to succeed in UMG.
So I like to follow three principles of
developing UI in UMG. The first is using
the right containers and keeping it
simple because UMG is inherently a
really complex tool and every layout
widget like containers we saw just now
they all have their own unique purposes
in how they lay out content widgets and
so content widgets always follow the
rules of their layout widgets. So let's
take a look at a couple examples to see
you know when should we use which layout
widget for what scenario right
let's talk about layering. So, we had
overlays, right? Overlays let you, you
know, organize your widgets top to
bottom using the hierarchy. That's a
really simple concept that most people
understand,
but this is really simple. And if you
want something a bit more than that, if
you want to specify, you know, I want
two widgets on the same layers, but I
want to make sure that that that's on
the very bottom and not the top, an
overlay doesn't really do it for me. And
so, I use a grid panel.
If you can see, there's a couple of
sparkles around, but they're overlaid on
top of the sign. Some is underneath the
sign. I have like that orange bar that's
overlaid on top of everything else. I

to bottom, you want to specifically

know, my sparkles offset all the way

bottoms, to the left, so on and so
forth.
Let's talk about ordering. So, another
really common use case in creating a UI
is that I want to start ordering my

and whatnot. We've talked about stack

Um, one thing I didn't mention about

the elements inside stack box can be

between the first two to be 50 pixels
and then 30 pixels and then 10. But if I
want to make a grid of let's say 25

such a hassle to update if I want to if
my designer if someone tells me that, oh
crap, we need to increase the pixels by

Right.
And that's where a uniform grid panel
comes in. This is not to be confused
with the grid panel. Okay. This is a
totally different widget. But what a
uniform grid panel does is this lets you
also create a grid. But the unique
property that it has is that you can
apply an equal you can apply a padding
to each one of these child elements in
there. So if I've defined 40 pixels of
padding for each child element, every
child element that I add inside a
uniform grid panel will have 40 pixels
of padding. And so this saves me the
trouble of, you know, going through each
one of them, applying padding to each or
removing it if I want to. Um, this just
saves 10 15 minutes of my time, right?
The next example is scaling. Um, I'm
pretty sure I've seen lots of people
struggle with how to scale things up.
Um, whether it's images, whether it's
text, whether it's even the container
itself. There are two main widgets that
we could use for scaling in UMG. And I
didn't cover these in the common um,
layout widgets, but these are a bit more
on the intermediate side of UMG where a
size box allows you to scale your
widgets non-proportionally. And so this
means that I could scale it and make it
a rectangle. I can make it a box. I can
make it really long but not wide. Um,
and that's because they have properties
called overwrite and min and max which
applies to the height and width of the
widget. While if I want proportional
scaling, let's say I want to keep my
rectangle rectangular as it scales up in
screen size, I could use a scale box and
applying, you know, applying widgets in
a scale box lets me scale it up
according to the aspect ratio that I
want. And if we look at this example, I
have my size box limited to a maximum
height. And so even if I scale it up,
the height remains the same. But you
notice that the width is also is
changing as a result. But the scale box
is still maintaining its aspect ratio as
you scale it up.
So that's principle number one. Um, keep
it simple, right? And that's going to be
a really common theme as we move out
move through this presentation in that
keeping it simple is always the way to
go in UMG.
The second principle that I like to
follow is know is a really simple one
but also really important to
understanding how containers work inside
UMG in that your layout widgets will
always size to what's the largest
content inside of it.
So in this scenario, I have two diamond
thingies, right? One's at 128 pixels,
the other's double in size.
As I scaled my image up, we can see that
the container also scaled up as a
result, right? And in isolation, this
can look fine. You know, like that's a
really simple concept to understand,
right?
Now, what happens if I put it with other
widgets like this? We can see that you
know the two smaller diamond images are
maintaining their own squares in there
but the larger one is taking up so much
space and if I use this with other
widgets inside my screen on my UI
screens um that's going to impact the
layout of other widgets inside it as
well. So that's something this is a
really small principle to keep in mind
but also really important to ensuring
that you don't get frustrated by how
your UI is moving around or how it's
being affected by just an image blowing
up like this.
And my third and actually favorite
principle for UMG which is I think
probably more important than the first
than keeping it simple is alignment.
This is the one thing that I find folks
don't normally do in UFN or don't
prioritize in UFN but alignment helps
you helps your widget scale up or down
and maintain its position when you know
your screen size goes up your screen
size goes down on mobile devices or TVs.
Um, it ensures that your widgets are
anchored and aligned to a specific
position inside your UI.
So, every single widget in UMG has these
two settings, horizontal alignment and
vertical alignment.
In this scenario, the diamond, this
diamond image is center aligned. And
center aligned on the horizontal axis
and vertical axis. If I set it to fill,
this fills the whole container. And so,
as my container scales up, this diamond
image will scale up as well. And so
understanding this concept means that my
diamond image which was originally 128
pixels is going to look extremely blurry
if I blow it up to you know a larger
widget than this right and if we take a
look at you know a widget with even more
even more you know variations than just
a diamond there's text there's the large
background behind these widgets are
currently aligned the text block on the
top left the other one on the bottom
right and the diamond in the center. And
so keeping these alignments, if we take
a look at this little video here, as my
widget scales up, it's going to be
anchored to the same corners as well.
And so this is a really simple example,
but as you scale your UI up and create
more complex widgets, alignment becomes
even more important because your widgets
might not be sizing perfectly as you
scale up or it might just be clashing
with each other as it scales down. And
so that's where alignment comes in in
that, you know, it helps you with what
we call responsive design, which is
design that adapts to different screen
sizes.
So these aren't the only three
principles of working UMG. There's a ton

with. Um, keeping these three in mind as

Okay, some rapid fire tips. I'm going to

Okay. First one. We know that padding

know that negative padding removes space

slider to a negative value. So try
adding try typing a negative value
inside padding. That removes space
between between widgets.
Next one. We've seen this drop down on
the top right of our UMG viewport, a
fill screen button. Most people don't
really understand what it's for, but all
you need to know is that fill screen
lets you preview your widget on how it
looks on a screen while desired lets you
preview your widget as its actual size.
And so depending on your use case,
whether you know are you designing your
widget by itself, use desired. If you're
design if you want to preview it to see
how it looks like on the mobile screen,
on the TV screen, use full screen.
Next, screen size. Following up with
that, there's this nifty two-way arrow
on the bottom right of every widget in
UMG and a little drop down on the top
right. They say screen size. This lets
you test how test how your UI looks on
different screens. You can drag that
arrow and increase the screen size to
see how your UI looks on a bigger screen
or smaller screen or you can pick from
pre-selected um screen sizes that we
provide you with using that drop down.
The fourth is wrap and replace with.
If you find yourself, you know, deep in
your widget hierarchy with 20, 30
widgets um insert UMG and you're
wondering that crap, I need to make a
change. Do I just like create a new one?
No. Go to your hierarchy, right click on
the widgets you like to replace or add
something to it. Wrap with allows you to
wrap your widgets inside a layout
widget, while replace with lets you
replace that widget either with a layout
widget or its children inside.
